answers.answer: First, a urinalysis is a pretty good test for a urinary tract infection, so you should trust your doctor's diagnosis if that's what s/he found.  However, some STDs can mimic UTI, and many docs don't test for STDs unless the patient tells a full and complete story so the doc knows the risks.  Were you tested for STDs?Second, increased vaginal odor is the most common symptom of bacterial vaginosis (BV) or trichomoniasis.  BV is related to sexual activity, but isn't an STD in the usual sense; trich is a garden-variety STD, i.e. acquired from a partner.  Although BV or trich shouldn't be confused with UTI, it is possible.Third, your sexual history includes good and bad news about STD risk.  The good news is that you haven't had unprotected sex.  Of course, this depends on what you mean by "unprotected":  if you mean correct use of a condom every time, that's great.  The bad news is the history of "concurrency"--i.e., having 2 or more partners, at least one of which reflects a (presumably) non-committed partner who might have other partners.  (I can't make presumptions here--you know better than I can whether either your ongoing or new partner is likely to have had other partners.)Fourth, you don't say how old you are.  Statistically speaking, your STD risk is much higher if you and your partners are in your 20s than if you are, say, over 40.  Not zero if older, but a lot lower.Finally, unrelated to all the above:  Are you sure about "sugar" in the urine?  That means diabetes, which can predispose to yeast infections and to UTI.  Are you known to be a diabetic?  If not, please make sure you check this out further with your doctor.Bottom line on the STD risk:  Make sure your doctor checked for the common STDs and BV.  If so and if s/he says the UTI is definite, then you're probably home free from an STD perspective.  Be sure and recheck the "sugar" business.Good luck--  HHH, MD

No, my doctor did not test for any std's.  I've never been through any of this so I didn't know what to expect or to ask of her.  I told her all of my symptoms and all that she made me do is give her an urine sample.  Yes, I am sure that she said that there was sugar in my urine, but she didn't seem that concerned at this point.  She said that the "ph"in my urine tested a 5 and she said that is low.  She also asked me if I had a job that I sat all day long.  I do, I sit 10 hours a day.  She seemed to think all of this were reasons why I was having my symptoms.  I don't know if any of this matters, I am just trying to let you know what she has said.2nd...I always had protected sex with condoms.  No Exceptions!3rd...I am 23 years old so I guess I am more at risk.Thanks for responding quickly.

It is not my habit or intent to criticize a doctor's practice and/or knowledge, because there always is another side of the story and I have only heard yours.  But sitting all day is entirely irrelevant.  A sexual history should be routine in providing primary care for any 23-year-old woman; many docs skip it, but not many would fail to take a sexual history or to talk about STD risks in a patient with vaginal odor or other genital symptoms.Finally, putting off a pelvic after giving an antibiotic risks missing any STD that might have been present; if you happened to have chlamydia or gonorrhea, for example, the antibiotic for your (urinary tract?) infection might suppress it so the test will be negative.  But looking for a silver lining, maybe she sent a urine specimen for gonorrhea and chlamydia testing.  If so, it would remove my concern about the delayed pelvic exam and give me more hope that your doctor is more aware of STD issues than I implied above.A urine pH of 5 is normal; on the low side of normal, but not unusual.Follow-up on the sugar in the urine; even if it goes away, even a single test showing sugar in the urine indicates a need for more tests to check the diabetes possibility.HHH, MD

question: Hello,Let me tell you a little about my situation.  I have been with someone for about 4 years.  Then about a year ago, I met someone else and began sleeping with him.I haven't had sex with #2 since August and am not seeing him anymore.  I have continued to have sex with my spouse.I am afraid that I have contacted something.  Let me say though, I had and have protected sex in fear of pregnancy.  I have never had unprotected sex.I've never had any burning or discomfort during unrination or sex.  I don't carry a fever and don't bleed in between periods. I don't have any burning or itching. I do have however a different sent and discharge, more than normal.  My "smell" isn't horrible, it's just different that what I am of custom to. Let me also say that I have a very weak bladder.  I went to see my Doctor, hoping that I have some type of Bladder infection.  She tested my urine to find I have blood and sugar in my urine.  She put me on an antibotic, saying that I have an infection.Maybe that is all it is, but I am still concerend.  I feel like I'm not getting any better yet.  I go back to the doctor in 2 weeks for another check and to get a pelvic exam.  I will know for sure then, although the agony of not knowing is driving me insane.  Please respond.  Thanks.
title: unsure
